awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Securing Cyberspace: Gaining Deep Insights into the Online Underground Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
As the Internet becomes increasingly ubiquitous, it offers a low-risk harbor for cybercrime -- illegal activities such as hacking and online scams. Cybercrime is increasingly enabled by an online underground ecosystem, within which are anonymous forums and so-called dark web platforms for cybercriminals to exchange knowledge and trade in illicit products and services. To better protect the trust of legitimate institutions and users within cyberspace, and to disrupt or mitigate the harm of illegal markets, there is an urgent need to gain deep insights into the online underground ecosystem and understand its intricate relationships. The goal of this project is to design and develop an integrated computational framework for in-depth investigation of the online underground ecosystem and thus to help secure cyberspace by producing data-driven interventions of cybercrimes. 

The research will have three main parts. First, the research team will design methods and develop algorithmic and scalable techniques to automate the analysis of online underground markets. Second, the team will develop a novel framework for cross-market user identification and profiling. Third, the team will design an innovative model and propose algorithms for structural analysis of cybercriminal social networks to gain deep insights into the organization and operation of cybercriminals in the ecosystem. The broader impacts of this work include benefits to scientific communities and society as a whole by developing interventions into online crime to secure cyberspace for its users. The establishment of a cybersecurity lab through this project will enhance education and workforce training in cybersecurity. The project integrates research with education through curriculum development, the participation of underrepresented groups, and student mentoring activities for a newly-established cybersecurity degree program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Cybercrimes have become increasingly dependent on the online underground ecosystem which has evolved into a complex and decentralized system resistant to infiltration. As more and more social activities have moved online, society’s overwhelming reliance on complex cyberspace makes its security more important than ever. To protect legitimate users in cyberspace against evolving cyber threats, this CAREER project aims to design and develop an integrated framework (algorithms, scalable techniques) for in-depth investigation of the online underground ecosystem and thus to help secure cyberspace by producing data-driven interventions of cybercrimes. The work in this project includes three key research components: (1) design methods and develop an effective model to automate the analysis of online underground markets in the forms such as social media platforms, underground forums and dark webs; (2) design methods and develop a novel framework for cross-market user identification and profiling; and (3) design an innovative model and propose algorithms for structural analysis of cybercriminal social network to gain deep insights into the organization and operation of cybercriminals in the ecosystem. With the support of this grant, during the project period, the PI and her team have had 66 publications in recognized journals (e.g., ACM TIST, ACM TKDD, IEEE TBD, Decision Support Systems, Information & Management, TMLR) and in proceedings of highly competitive conferences with acceptance rate about or less than 20% (e.g., AAAI'2021-2023 & 2025, NDSS'2025, ACM IUI'2025, UAI'2024, WWW'2019, 2021 & 2023-2024, ICLR'2023-2024, ICML'2023-2024, NeurIPS'2021-2023, ICDM'2023, CIKM'2021-2023, WSDM'2023, SIGKDD'2022, SDM'2022, IJCAI'2019 & 2022, ACSAC'2019-2020, etc.). The project also resulted in 5 Ph.D. dissertations and 1 Master Thesis. The research outcomes have been widely disseminated to research communities and practitioners through the publications, presentations, seminars, project website and demos, media presses, etc. Especially, with partial support of this project, the PI has received the prestigious IJCAI Early Career Spotlight (2019), the AICS 2019 Challenge Problem Winner, the ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Runner Up (Applied Track), WWW 2021 Best Paper Award Shortlist, SIGKDD 2022 Best Paper Award Shortlist, and the AAAI-DCAA 2023 Best Paper Runner-Up.

By probing into the evolving online underground forums, the proposed techniques and integrated framework developed in this project will help law enforcement and security defenders identify threats driven by the online underground ecosystem, produce effective countermeasures to disrupt underground market operations, and predict evolving trajectories of cybercrimes. Specifically, by engaging with the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), PI Ye's extensive work on combating online opioid trafficking received the award-winning "What Would You Fight For (WWYFF)?" series, which was aired on NBC to millions of audiences to raise awareness of this critical societal issue on October 28, 2023 in the "Red Robbin Week"; due to the significant societal impact, it was re-aired on NBC-Peacock and the stadium during the Notre Dame football game on September 28, 2024. In addition to the broader societal impact, the proposed research in this project will be beneficial to researchers and practitioners in multidisciplinary areas. The techniques developed in this project can be used in various security domains (e.g., spammer detection, combat against mis/disinformation) and applicable in different learning tasks in AI/data science (e.g., classification, network/graph embedding). Moreover, this project will also generate interdisciplinary research impacts - i.e., developing innovative links between AI/data science and cybersecurity to gain deep insights into the online underground ecosystem is likely to have increasingly significant impacts across different disciplines. The innovations in AI and data science that are advanced in this project will reshape the landscape of research combating evolving cybercrimes. The outcomes of this project (including open-source code and benchmark datasets) have been made publicly accessible; and broadly distributed through publications, presentations, seminars, demonstrations, etc. The project has integrated research with education through novel curriculum development, engaging postdoc, graduate and undergraduate students in research. Through various K-12 and community outreach activities, this project has also broadened participation in computing especially in the areas of AI, data science, and cybersecurity.

 


Last Modified: 04/07/2025
Modified by: Yanfang Ye
